awd_titl_txt: A Critical Examination of the Model for Insect Body Size Determination: the Mechanisms of Body Size Variation in Bees
awd_abstract_narration:
Growth rate and the timing of when growth stops determine body size, an important trait for survival and reproduction. The cues that stop growth are not fully understood, even in well-studied model species. Solitary bees provision their offspring, restricting the food available for larval growth. Experiments indicate that the complete consumption of these provisions induces metamorphosis. Studying the cues to metamorphosis in solitary bees provides a unique opportunity to physiologically compare individuals of the same age and size that either have or have not transitioned to metamorphosis. The proposed research will investigate (1) whether the hormonal cues underlying starvation-triggered metamorphosis in solitary bees are the same as those found in insects that metamorphose upon reaching a particular size, (2) how variation in the timing of metamorphosis predicts body size variation in natural populations and different bee species, and (3) how the determinants of adult size in bees shape differences between queens and workers in honeybees. Bee body size predicts pollination performance, and a physiological understanding of body size control has direct implications for pollinator health and performance in both natural and managed bee species, whether solitary or social. Undergraduates, graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow will participate in this research, and K-12 learning modules on pollinator life cycles will be developed.

Body size is an important organismal trait that correlates with most aspects of performance and fitness. In determinant-growing organisms, body size becomes fixed at maturation; therefore the mechanisms regulating maturation also influence size variation among individuals. Insects grow as larvae until attainment of a critical weight, at which point the mechanisms regulating metamorphosis are irreversibly initiated. This established model of body size control may not be generalizable to species with larval ecologies that differ from model insect species. Preliminary data demonstrate that completely consuming the larval provision initiates metamorphosis in the solidary bee Osmia lignaria. This result challenges the existing conceptual model for insect body size by suggesting that the critical weight is not a universal trait in insects. The proposed research will address three central aims: 1) characterizing the physiological regulation of metamorphosis in the solitary bee Osmia lignaria, 2) characterizing factors determining body size variation among populations and species of solitary bees that share similar larval ecologies; and 3) testing the degree to which diet quantity contributes to caste differences in eusocial bees. These mechanisms have the potential to explain much of the body size variation observed among Hymenopterans. Finally, the proposed research will develop a mechanistically explicit understanding of body size determination for bees, which are key pollinators for natural and managed ecosystems. A deeper, mechanistic understanding of body size variation may yield insights into improving pollinator health at the scale of individuals or even populations.  Results from these studies will be disseminated in peer reviewed journals and through presentations at scientific meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Body size in most animals is strongly linked to performance. In insects that go through metamorphosis, which includes bees, butterflies, beetles, and many other species, adult body size is thought to be regulated by a critical weight that determines the initiation of metamorphosis. However, the critical weight has only been measured in a few insect species and may not be a unifying feature of insect metamorphosis. We tested whether solitary bees use a critical weight to initiate metamorphosis. In solitary bees, the mother bee determines the amount of food each offspring receives by regulating the size of the provision she collects. This provision-based life history is different from the life cycle of model insect species, but is a common strategy in bees and some beetles. We tested the regulation of metamorphosis in two solitary bee species, the blue orchard bee Osmia lignaria and the alfalfa leafcutting bee Megachile rotundata. We discovered that solitary bees do not use a critical weight to initiate metamorphosis.  Rather, the larva initiate metamorphosis when they finish their provision. We measured juvenile hormone production and gene expression during metamorphosis to see if solitary bees use the same physiological processes as insects that use a critical weight mechanism. We found many similarities, indicating that conserved physiological mechanisms underly these two different life history signals. Solitary bee larvae initiated metamorphosis even when we manipulated provision size to be very small, which allowed us to generate adult bees that had a ten-fold range of body sizes. We tested whether this range of body sizes had implications for flight performance. Large adults had exaggerated growth of the thorax as compared to small adults. While this might suggest better flight performance by enhanced growth of flight muscles, small adults had a higher lift capacity because their wings were proportionately larger, and they had less body mass to lift during flight. Thus, the maxim that 'bigger is better' is not necessarily true when examining traits related to flight performance in solitary bees.

We also examined regulation of body size in honey bees, which are a social species. Honey bee queens differ from workers in behavioral traits, morphology, and body size. Royal jelly in the larval diet is thought to regulate the difference between queen-destined and worker-destined larvae. Yet, the role of food quantity and the critical weight had never been investigated. We determined that food quantity, more so than quality, contributes to the development of queen-like traits. We also found that honey bees, unlike solitary bees, use a critical weight mechanism to regulate metamorphosis.

The solitary bee species used in this research are both managed species and contribute significantly to agricultural pollination. Especially small individuals of solitary bee species have been observed in years with reduced floral resources. Our work suggests that these small adults may not necessarily be at a disadvantage with respect to flight performance and that adjusting body size to match food availability may be common in solitary bees. Furthermore, honey bee populations are facing large annual losses, and declining queen quality has been noted by beekeepers in annual surveys. Our work suggests that nutrition is an important consideration in commercial production of high-quality queens. This research resulted in 44 presentations at professional meetings and 14 peer-reviewed publications in academic journals. The grant supported the training of two postdoctoral scholars, two graduate students, and 12 undergraduates. Seven of the trainees were women and six of the trainees were from groups traditionally underrepresented in science. Undergraduates research was supported through the Pollination Nation summer research program that involved students from minority serving institutions and primarily undergraduate colleges. Most of our students participated in outreach to the community, providing education about pollinators and insects in general.
